collectionHeaderMetadata.title: Adventures in Consumer Technology

paragraphs.text: Apple’s current strategy of simply tacking these features on rather than rethinking their fundamental interaction model results in products like iTunes (and iTunes Store)—layered legacy code and all. Indeed, this would help explain why iOS has felt less polished and buggy of late.

paragraphs.name: 92d3
paragraphs.text: The overall result? A platform with neglected apps and waning developer interest, and a product that has yet to produce a compelling value proposition.

paragraphs.name: 9df1
paragraphs.text: Further, iCloud should be treated as more than a hard drive in the cloud. Apple should eliminate the need for endless login screens on multiple devices by expanding iCloud Keychain into an identity solution. iCloud should provide automatic app data sync by allowing users to restore previously backed-up app data when re-downloading an app, rather than requiring an entire device restore through iCloud Backup. Siri data should be synced to iCloud to personalise each of the user’s devices.

paragraphs.name: 92d3
paragraphs.text: The overall result? A platform with neglected apps and waning developer interest, and a product that has yet to produce a compelling value proposition.

paragraphs.name: 3cff
paragraphs.text: I have written extensively about Apple’s problems with services originating from their hardline privacy stance. However, there is another major issue: Apple views services as a value-adding feature, rather than a discrete platform. This stems from their hardware-centric business model, which is accordingly reflected in their device-centred services approach. The problem is that services are eating software, and now often indistinguishable from each other. Therefore, Apple should be treating their services with equal importance as iOS, macOS and tvOS: iCloud should be best-in-class; Siri should be more than just souped-up Voice Control; Apple Music shouldn’t delete people’s music libraries; these services should work seamlessly across all their devices and platforms — even on the web.

Apple has somewhat recognised this recently, using Siri branding on their Proactive features (e.g. Siri App Suggestions). The problem is it’s merely a half-step; Siri is still treated as an OS-dependent feature where Apple cherry-picks which features will appear where. This results in fragmented experiences such as outlined above. As for iCloud, it performs horribly on the web, often has cross-device syncing problems and even experiences data loss issues. This is a far cry from Steve’s original vision of seamless cloud computing.
paragraphs.name: 4d67

paragraphs.text: The overall result? A platform with neglected apps and waning developer interest, and a product that has yet to produce a compelling value proposition.
paragraphs.name: 92d3
4d67

The problem is it’s merely a half-step; Siri is still treated as an OS-dependent feature where Apple cherry-picks which features will appear where. This results in fragmented experiences such as outlined above. As for iCloud, it performs horribly on the web, often has cross-device syncing problems and even experiences data loss issues. This is a far cry from Steve’s original vision of seamless cloud computing.
Meanwhile, Amazon has done a better job at making content — not apps — the focal point:
paragraphs.name: 922b

paragraphs.text: Furthermore, Apple’s unrefined approach of simply sticking an entire App Store on it has resulted in a product no different from Android TV — blown-up smartphone games and all. Not every app category needs to be present on the Apple TV:
paragraphs.name: ad36

paragraphs.text: Apple needs to realise that services are just as much the soul of their products, as the hardware is the brain and sinew.
paragraphs.name: 6c0d

78a63e88ef38.title: When the soul dies, but the body lives on, we have a hard time discerning life from death.

paragraphs.text: When the soul dies, but the body lives on, we have a hard time discerning life from death. The problem with Apple isn’t its products. They are merely symptoms. The problem is the company lacks vision and purpose. It no longer sees what’s missing from the world, only what else it can stuff into it. It’s a subtle shift at first, but when even the…

e6ffd1effb6d.title: Don’t get me started on Apple Photos metadata.

paragraphs.text: Don’t get me started on Apple Photos metadata. I moved to Google Photos because apple insists that each of my devices independently scan photos to identify faces, places and objects. The worst is that I have to do a lot of human editing (merging faces) afterwards, and even that effort is not synced.

paragraphs.text: Very great read! Sadly, I can agree with most of it. Most of that could be submitted as radars to Apples bug reporting tool as well, and I am happy to duplicate them… That’s what Apple is telling developers to do, all the time. So why not file things like this as well?

457e615688d3.title: I agree with a lot of these, especially the Apple Watch notes.

paragraphs.text: I agree with a lot of these, especially the Apple Watch notes. I’ve had mine since launch and I love it, but there are nagging issues that haven’t gone away. Namely snappiness and far too many apps that have no purpose on a wrist. The app cloud is just a horrible paradigm. I think the side button doesn’t need to be there as well. I love the wheel but…
paragraphs.name: 4ab5

paragraphs.text: Excellent points! Especially those regarding leadership. Steve was right: his most important “product” was the leadership team he built. And subsequently the teams his leaders built were just as important. I’m not sure that product exists anymore. When Ron Johnson left as head of retail, there was a change in store culture and focus as well. Store…

56ec9f483caf.title: Apple just doesn’t get open web.

paragraphs.text: Apple just doesn’t get open web. Their second try of Ping aka iTunes Connect is the weirdest social network in that it’s only accessible inside a music app, not a browser.
